key_insight: A panoramic metric-depth foundation model can generalize across a wide range of scene distances by training on a carefully curated, multi-source dataset and a staged pseudo-supervision pipeline that reduces synthetic/real and indoor/outdoor domain gaps.
problem_solved: Panoramic depth estimation lacks large, diverse metric-depth training data and struggles to produce accurate, scale-aware depths across indoor and outdoor scenes; this work addresses dataset scarcity and domain mismatch to enable robust panoramic metric depth prediction.
method: Data-in-the-loop construction: combine public panoramic depth datasets, high-fidelity UE5 synthetic panoramas, text-to-image synthetic panoramas, and real web panoramas to form a large, diverse training corpus.
Three-stage pseudo-supervision pipeline: staged training and pseudo-labeling strategies to align synthetic and real domains and to calibrate metric scale across near and far scene distances.
Foundation-model design for panoramas: a scale-aware panoramic encoder + depth head trained to output metric depth maps that generalize across diverse scene distances (indoor/outdoor).
impact: Provides a practical foundation model and dataset strategy that lets practitioners obtain reliable, scale-aware depth from panoramas for robotics, AR/VR, mapping, and large-scale scene understanding without per-scene calibration.

paper_title: Depth Any Panoramas: A Foundation Model for Panoramic Depth Estimation
paper_authors: Xin Lin, Meixi Song, Dizhe Zhang, Wenxuan Lu, Haodong Li
